_prev_prog_3.Description: Arkema Inc., Coating Resins, uses bulk monomers and ammonia as part of its emulsion polymers process to produce water-borne latex.  An operating process is used to produce the latex, which is a non-flammable, non-toxic product.  The latex produced at this site is sold to coating manufacturers.  Some of the products made from the lates produced at this facility are: paints, caulks, adhesives, and sealants.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Arkema Inc has prepared this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Torrance Coating Resin plant in accordance with Section 2745.10 of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  In accordance with paragraph (a) of this section, the update has been prepared within 5 years of the date of the original submittal.  (The plan was last submitted to the Torrance Fire Department [the Administering Agency] in April 2010.)

The following activities were conducted in support of the RMP Update, in accordance with Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP guidance for updates:

* The Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) for the facility was revised by Arkema using a proprietary technique.  

* The Offsite Consequence Analysis was revised using a current version of RMP*Comptm.  The affected population and list of sensitive receptors was revised using current population data and other resources.  

* The seismic analysis for the affected systems was reviewed for changes to the system, changes to the building codes that may impact affected systems, and implementation of recommendations made in the last seismic review.  

* A three-year compliance audit was conducted by an outside environmental contractor, in accordance with Section 2760.8 of the CalARP regulations.  

* A revised RMP*Submittm has been prepared to reflect the changes in the RMP program since the 2004 update.  These revisions include the activities noted above in addition to routine updates of the various written compliance plans and programs.  

This Executive Summary discusses the current status of each of the RMP program elements.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES 

Arkema has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  Arkema is committed to operating and maintaining all of the processes in a safe and responsible manner.  Arkema has implemented a combination of accident release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safet

y of its employees and the public, as well as to protect the environment.  These programs include both Arkema Responsible Care requirements and governmental requirements, such as EPA's RMP rule, and the CalARP RMP requirements.

DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES 

Arkema Coating Resin facility, located in Torrance, California, operates a latex emulsion manufacturing facility that produces more than 100 million pounds of latex per year.  The water-borne latex produced at this site is utilized by the coatings industry to make latex-based paints, caulks, adhesives, and sealants.  The facility is recognized as a covered source under the RMP rule as the facility maintains quantities of regulated substances listed in the RMP rule above the applicable thresholds.  The facility does not maintain specified quantities of any RMP regulated flammable substances, but does utilize the following RMP regulated toxic substances at levels above threshold limits: 

* Vinyl Acetate monomer (VAM) (acetic acid ethenyl ester, CAS 107-13-1) and Aqueous Ammonia (CAS 7664-41-7)

The facility no long uses acrylonitrile (2-propenenitrile, CAS 108-05-4).  The former acrylonitrile storage tank is used for the storage of vinyl versate, a substance not regulated RMP in the program.  The revisions to the RMP addressed in this 5-year update address the elimination of acrylonitrile as a regulated substance at the facility.

HAZARD ASSESSMENT

RMP regulations require that each facility identify worst-case and alternative release scenarios.  EPA has defined a worst-case release as the release of the entire contents of the largest vessel that contains a regulated substance in a 10-minute period.  EPA defines alternative release scenarios as scenarios that are more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario, and that reach an endpoint offsite, unless no such scenario exists.  One or more alternative release scenarios are evaluated to define the distance to the specified endpoint.  Un

less otherwise specified, no credit was taken for administrative controls or active mitigation measures in evaluating the off-site impact of the scenarios.

Prediction of the zone of potential impact for the worst-case and alternative releases was performed using RMP*Comp (Version 1.07) released by EPA.  RMP*Comp is an electronic tool to make the same calculations performed manually by following the procedures described in EPA's guidance document, RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance (April, 1999).  

Worst-Case Release Scenarios

VAM is stored at the Arkema Terminal facility and is fed by pipeline on an as-needed basis for batch processing during the manufacturing of latex.  Monomer mix tank number 4 (MMT-4) can hold the largest quantity of VAM, 4,500 gallons.  The monomer mixing area is surrounded by a small dike sufficient to contain the contents of a spill of the maximum amount of VAM on-site in a monomer mixing tank.  The dike dimensions are approximately 50 feet by 50 feet by 4 inches deep.   

The worst-case release of VAM assumes the catastrophic failure of MMT-4.  The worst-case meteorological conditions defined by EPA for the worst-case release are a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second (m/s) and a stability class of F (very stable).  For VAM, the worst-case distance to the threshold concentration of 0.26 mg/l is 0.7 miles (1,100 meters).

Aqueous ammonia will be stored in a 5,000 gallon storage tank with secondary containment.  According to the CalARP Program Regulations, the worst case release scenario analyzed considered the entire 5,000 gallon tank of aqueous ammonia to spill suddenly, flow rapidly into the secondary containment area (~1,500 square feet of area), and immediately form a pool there.  This corresponds to 10,460 pounds of ammonia in the solution.

The worst-case release of Aqueous ammonia assumes the catastrophic failure of the storage tank.  The worst-case meteorological conditions defined by EPA for the worst-case release are a wind

speed of 1.5 meters per second (m/s) and a stability class of F (very stable).  For Aqueous ammonia, the worst-case distance to the threshold concentration of 0.14 mg/l is 0.4 miles.



Alternative-Release Scenarios

Two alternative release scenarios for VAM were assessed.  VAM alternative scenario #1 consists of an unconfined release from the three-inch pipeline from the Arkema Terminal to the monomer mix tank area.  The distance to the threshold concentration of 0.26 mg/l is 0.2 miles (300 meters) for VAM alternative scenario #1.  VAM alternative scenario #2 assumes an open ?-inch drain valve on the discharge side of a pump while transferring VAM to an intermediate mix tank.  The distance to the threshold for VAM alternative scenario 2 is approximately 0.2 miles (300 meters).

A total of 7,100 persons in 2,650 households reside within the VAM worst-case impact distance, based on the 2000 Census data.  The sensitive receptors within 0.7 miles of the facility include schools, parks, and recreational areas.  Other potential receptors include industrial facilities and major commercial facilities.  For the alternative impact distance of 0.2 miles, there are no sensitive receptors.  The estimated population potentially effected by the alternative release scenario is an estimated 100 persons.  

Mitigation

The specific systems to prevent the worst-case and alternative release scenarios of VAM from occurring, as well as mitigate their effects should they occur, include: 

* Emergency Shutdown Systems: A manual emergency shutdown system is designed to shutdown the pumps and put the transfer valves in a fail-safe position. 

* Surveillance: Operations personnel routinely monitor the process and facility perimeters two times per shift.  The facility operates four 12-hour shifts per day, seven days per week. 

Aqueous ammonia is unloaded from a tank truck via a 2 inch diameter hose that is connected to the integral truck mounted on board feed pump.  The hose is also connecte

d to the nozzle of the storage tank.  The operator mistakenly sets the feed flow rate higher than the designed flow rate.  The high flow causes high pressure in the hose, resulting in rupture of the hose an ammonia releases into the secondary containment area.  The operator observes the rupture and manually shuts off the control valve on the storage tank and feed pump.  Five minutes elapse between the time the rupture occurs and the spill is stopped.  It is assumed that the feed pump was operating at a flow rate of 40 gallon per minute (gpm) (~84 pounds per minute) when the rupture occurred.  Therefore, 200 gallons of aqueous ammonia is released to the 1500 square foot secondary containment area, and evaporates at a rate determined by its volatilization rate.  This corresponds to 418 pounds of ammonia in the solution.  No mitigation measures were used for the modeling.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at Arkema facility in Torrance, California.  Arkema general accident prevention program consists of compliance with the EPA and CalARP regulations as well as implementation of Arkema Loss Prevention Principles and Episodic Risk Management System.  General accident prevention program consists of compliance with the following rules:

* California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program

* 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention (RMP rule)

* 40 CFR Part 264, Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan

* 40 CFR Part 355, Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA)

The following is a brief outline of the general accident prevention program in place at Arkema portion of the facility.

Compliance Audits

In accordance with Section 2760.8 of the CalARP regulations, a three-year compliance audit was conducted by an outside environmental contractor, AECOM Environment, using a modified EPA RMP audit protocol.  T

he audit findings noted the following deficiency:

* The OCA required revision because the facility eliminated the use and storage of acrylonitrile. 

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Arkema periodically conducts corporate and plant-led audits to ensure that process operations comply with governmental and Arkema requirements.

Contractor Safety Program 

Arkema uses contractors to supplement its work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. During procurement of contractor services, the purchasing procedures require the verification of training and if applicable, certifications and licenses. Prior to initiating work at the facility, contractors are required to attend a safety briefing, which is documented and retained. Some contractors are required to work on or near process equipment; therefore, the facility has established procedures to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform facility personnel of any hazards that are found during their work. At least one Arkema employee is assigned to each contractor. The Arkema employee is responsible for checking the work of each contractor to ensure Arkema procedures are followed. 

Employee Participation 

Arkema encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management, behavior based safety and accident prevention.  Arkema engages its employees through formal and informal means. The management of change process is an intranet-based workflow process that requires each affected employee (i.e., Acknowledger) to review and acknowledge acceptance of the change or changes.  The Acknowledger has the opportunity to raise concerns prior to finalizing changes at the facility.  At the beginning of

each shift, a Shift Concerns Meeting is conducted to discuss issues and concerns covering all aspects of the employee's work. Employees have access either through Arkema intranet site or on-site library to information created as part of the facility accident prevention program. Employees are encouraged to participate in the accident prevention program. The plan is documented and maintained on Arkema intranet site and on-site library. In addition, employees are involved in other aspects of the operation including, but not limited to, periodic inspections, operating procedure creation, and incident investigations.

Episodic Risk Management System 

Periodic reviews are conducted to identify hazards that could have significant community impact and to recommend corrective action(s) needed to prevent their occurrence.  These reviews utilize advanced quantitative risk assessment techniques. 

Equipment Design 

Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are designed according to recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements. 

Incident Investigation 

Arkema promptly investigates all incidents that result in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the root cause of the incident by reviewing facts and developing corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The production leader is responsible for incident investigations at the facility.  Each shift has an immediate response coordinator responsible for implementing the RMP, including incident investigation.  No incidents occurred in the past 5 years that required incident investigation.

Management of Change 

Arkema has a robust system to ensure that modifications to facilities and processes are reviewed by the appropriate technical staff, management, and affected employees (i.e., Acknowledgers). Thi

s is an electronic workflow process located on Arkema Intranet site. The management of change requests are controlled and tracked to completion. This process requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before implementation. Specifically, the change is only initiated after each employee (reviewer or Acknowledger) has acknowledged his/her review and approval on the proposed change. At this point, the facility is authorized to move forward with implementation of the change. 

Mechanical Integrity 

Arkema has well-established practices and procedures to maintain tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps, transfer hoses, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) developing written procedures, (2) conducting training, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  A preventative maintenance system (SAP) is used to track work orders, calibration schedules, testing and certification schedules, and completion of all the above. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the facility's process equipment. 

Operating Procedures 

Arkema maintains written procedures that provide detail on how to safely operate a process, including various modes of process operations, such as unit startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.  The procedures are maintained up-to-date by revising them as necessary. 

Operational Safety Pro

gram 

Arkema has a comprehensive program to ensure that all the elements listed within this accidental release prevention program are implemented at every Arkema location.  This program includes accountabilities for timely and proper implementation of the program elements. 

Loss Prevention Principles 

Design requirements for active and passive mitigation controls used to prevent major process hazards are documented in Loss Prevention Principles (LPP). 

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) 

Arkema conducts reviews just prior to startup to ensure that new and modified facilities and processes are safe for operation.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented. 

Process Hazard Analysis

Arkema conducted an internal audit of the facility on March 24 and 25, 2009.  A PHA was conducted during the audit using Arkema proprietary Reactive Chemical Process Hazard Analysis (RCPHA).  The principal staff performing the RCPHA was Marco Barrueta (Production Leader), Erwin Morfe (Run Plant Engineer), Ronald Weber (Plant EHS/Training), and Yin Ko (Plant Improvement/Projects).  This RCPHA audit is an update to the PHA/Hazard Operability Study (HazOp) performed for the original Risk Management Prevention Program (RMPP) plan and the RMP.  

The RCPHA methodology consists of a checklist designed by Arkema for use in internal reactive chemical and PHA audits.  For each question in the checklist, there are columns for a yes/no/not applicable response, a response column, columns to check the work discipline affected, and an action item column.  In addition to the RCPHA questionnaire, there is a second questionnaire that is used for field validation to be used in conjunction with the RCPHA.

There have been no significant changes to the VAM process at the facility since the preparation of the previous RMP and PHA.  The acrylonitrile proc

ess was removed and no acrylonitrile is stored on the property.

As part of the RMP Update, the RCPHA developed during the March 2009 audit was reviewed by AECOM for completeness and applicability. There were no significant findings identified during the RCPHA or during AECOM's review of the RCPHA.  All RCPHA audit action items were entered into Arkema Event and Action Tool (i.e., database) and each item was assigned for follow-up.



External Events Analysis

The 1999 RMPP seismic assessment of the facility estimated the seismic vulnerability of vessels, piping, and associated equipment and structures containing regulated substances.  In addition, vessels not containing regulated substances but which could impact vessels or piping containing regulated substances during a large earthquake were also evaluated.  The 1999 RMPP seismic review was performed according to the requirements in the 1998 Guidance for CalARP Seismic Assessment.  AECOM reviewed the seismic assessment portion of the RMPP seismic assessment conducted in December 1995, the October 1999 seismic update for the facility, and ENSR's Review of CalARP Seismic Assessment and Walkthrough Findings for the facility conducted in December 2003.  After the review, AECOM conducted a walkthrough at the facility to confirm whether recommended modifications had been completed.

Based on AECOM's review of the recommendations provided in the 1999 seismic assessment, the 2003 seismic update, and a walkthrough of the facility, it appears that the modifications recommended in those assessments have been adequately implemented.  No additional areas of concern were identified during AECOM's walkthrough.  

Process Safety Information 

Arkema keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the process.  Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information is documented, maintained up-to-date and available to operating personnel. 

Chemical-specific information, including ex

posure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs).  For specific process areas, the facility has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, pressure and level control) in the LPP documents.  The facility ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, automated operating systems, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems). 

The facility maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a means for establishing inspection and maintenance activities. 

Safe Work Practices 

Arkema has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a hot work permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities, and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely. 

Training/Certification Programs 

To complement the written procedures for process operations, Arkema has implemented a comprehensive training and certification program for all employees involved in operating a process.  After employees demonstrate having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own (e.g., through tests, skills demonstrati

on), they are certified to work independently.  In addition, trained technical staff is available 24 hours a day to support operations. 

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 

In the last five years there has not been an accident or incident involving a release of VAM and ammonia from affected systems at the facility that resulted in an on-site death, injury, or property damage; or a known off-site death, injury, evacuation, shelter-in-place, property damage or environmental damage. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION 

The facility maintains a written emergency response program to protect worker and public safety, as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of hazardous substances, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including: 

* Proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, 

* Evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation,

* Notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, 

* Post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements (if a release occurs), and 

* Inspecting, testing, maintaining, and using emergency response equipment. 

The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. 

The overall emergency response program for Arkema in Torrance is coordinated with the Torrance Fire Department and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  Arkema conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the appropriate emergency response organizations. 

In addition, Arkema Hazardous Emergency Leaks Prevention (HELP) team located in Torrance responds to accidental releases from transportation incidents occurring in the continental U.S. 

The emergency response program provides the essent

ial planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Detailed emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the Torrance Fire Department. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

Arkema completed a thorough review of the affected VAM / Ammonia system(s) each time a design change is implemented and reviews the standard operating procedures every three years.  Arkema audit team revalidates the PHA every five years from the date of the initial PHA.  Arkema is committed to using these methods to identify and implement ways to improve the safety of these systems.  These on-going programs aim to improve process safety.

Based on the compliance audit, review of the OCA, PHA, and seismic assessment, no changes to the management or equipment is recommended at this time.
